Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Systematic Evaluation and Further Improvement of Present Broadband Radiative Transfer Modeling Capabilities
Award.AbstractNarration:
The terrestrial climate system is sensitive to the radiation budget. Thus, accurate knowledge about the solar and thermal infrared radiation in the coupled atmosphere-ocean system is critical to robust climate study. An example of this sensitivity is the suggestion that a 1% decrease in the solar constant could lead to an ice age. The effect of doubling CO2 on radiative forcing is approximately 4 Wm-2, whereas uncertainties in radiation simulations due to, for example, insufficient knowledge about the optical properties of clouds, may be larger than this value. During the 1980s and 1990s, many researchers made substantial progress in developing and improving radiative transfer schemes used in general climate models (GCMs), and various intercomparisons of GCM radiation codes were published. Since that time, significant progress has been made in light scattering computational methods, in-situ measurements and laboratory studies of the optical and microphysical properties of clouds and aerosols, gaseous absorption line parameters and the water vapor continuum absorption, optical properties of various oceanic constituents, and the efficiency of numerical schemes for solving radiative transfer equations. There is a pressing need to incorporate the aforesaid progress into radiative transfer modeling capabilities. Moreover, the ocean and atmosphere are not coupled in many existing radiative transfer models. The scattering and absorption of radiation by oceanic water, dissolved organic matter (the so-called yellow substance), and phytoplankton have an influence in heating the uppermost water layers, and consequently affect thermal and dynamic properties such as the sea surface temperature and depth of the mixed atmosphere-ocean layer. The reflection of radiation by the oceans, including the effects of a wavy air-water interface and whitecap, can also affect the spectral characteristics and magnitude of radiation and, thus, the radiative heating and cooling rates in the atmosphere. The overarching goal is to systematically evaluate and further improve current radiative transfer modeling capabilities.

Intellectual Merit:
The outcomes of the study will include 1) systematic quantification of the potential errors/inaccuracies of the aforesaid radiative transfer models, 2) extension of the current radiative transfer modeling capabilities to an atmosphere-ocean coupled system, 3) implementation of spectrally consistent parameterizations of ice clouds and dust aerosols, and 4) development and implementation of a computationally efficient radiative transfer solver.

Broader Impacts:
The research effort will improve the radiative transfer package currently used in climate models, and be a valuable contribution to the atmospheric radiative transfer and climate study communities. Furthermore, the light scattering modeling and parameterization capabilities can find potential applications in other areas such as remote sensing of dust aerosol and ice cloud properties. The associated educational pursuits will focus on mentoring a postdoc researcher, training a graduate student, and developing teaching materials. This effort will contribute to training young researchers in the discipline of radiative transfer and light scattering that is a quite unique branch of atmospheric physics. Furthermore, the integration of RRTMG into classroom teaching will directly benefit the educational program in atmospheric sciences, particularly, in hands-on experience in atmospheric radiative transfer simulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was conducted based on close collaborations between a research group at Texas A&M University and a research group at Atmospheric and Environmental Research. The overarching goal of this project is to perform basic research to improve radiative transfer modeling capabilities. The research findings and improved radiative transfer modeling capabilities are anticipated to find applications in the radiative transfer simulations involved in weather studies and climate science. Summarized below are the major accomplishments of this project:

1) We thoroughly investigated the longwave (LW) scattering effect of clouds. The results show that neglecting cloud LW scattering in the previous RRTMG leads to a 2.6 W m-2 overestimation of the global annual mean outgoing LW radiation, suggesting that the warming effect of cloud LW scattering is nearly as large as doubling the CO2 concentration in the atmosphere. Using the Community Earth System Model (CESM) with including the LW scattering effects, we performed 45-year simulations and showed that inclusion of cloud LW scattering causes (a) additional atmospheric warming over the tropics and surface warming over polar areas and the Tibetan Plateau, (b) increased east-west wind speeds in the lower and upper troposphere over the tropical Pacific, and (c) a poleward shift of the midlatitude westerly winds in Southern Hemisphere summer. The results suggest that the long-lasting equatorward biases of the midlatitude westerly winds in climate simulations may be reduced if cloud LW scattering is accounted for.

2) We developed a radiative adjustment scheme based on the similarity principle and a previously reported scaling scheme. The adjustment scheme has been implemented in RRTM_LW and validated against the benchmarks computed by a rigorous radiative transfer model. In the adjustment scheme, the upward radiances are used to adjust the downward radiances. A negative adjustment term for the upward radiance is derived, which increases with cloud optical thickness and approaches a constant for very thick clouds. With the adjustment scheme, the top-of-the-atmosphere (TOA) upward and surface downward irradiance errors are reduced to less than 2 and 0.5 W m-2, respectively, over a wide range of optical thickness values. The comparison with the four-stream approximation shows that the new adjustment schemes are more accurate than the four-stream approximation and about 20 times faster. Furthermore, neglecting cloud LW scattering leads to an erroneous cooling effect beneath the cloud layer, which is however decreased, and almost eliminated, by the adjustment method. This adjustment approach has been adapted to the Radiative Transfer for Energetics plus RRTMG—Parallel (RTE+RRTMGP).

3) We developed an updated ocean surface albedo (OSA) computational scheme for modeling the impact of ocean phytoplankton populations on the boundary condition of solar radiative transfer in the atmosphere. The updated scheme was added into the RRTMG_SW. Comparing the updated OSA scheme and five other schemes with in-situ broadband shortwave OSA measurements, two of the selected schemes that consider multiple influential factors agree best with the measurements. The present scheme highly agrees with the Clouds and the Earth's Radiant Energy System (CERES) observed OSA distribution in global oceans, although this scheme shows small differences compared with the CERES OSA under all sky conditions and overestimates the CERES OSA in the subpolar Southern Ocean under clear sky conditions. The assumption of using a global mean ocean particle phase function, ignoring the spatial variability of ocean particles, leads to a primary source of uncertainties in the updated OSA scheme.

4) We have implemented new spectrally consistent parameterizations of ice cloud bulk radiative properties in RRTM and RRTMG. In addition, we have developed/documented a comprehensive database of the optical properties of dust aerosol. Because the index of refraction of dust varies with geolocation, it is more straightforward to use dust optical property data tables instead of developing a unified parameterization scheme.  

5) The scattering phase functions of liquid cloud droplets and ice cloud particles in the atmosphere show strong forward peaks. We developed a computationally efficient program to deal with the forward peak of the phase function in radiative transfer simulations. In particular, the small-angle approximation (SAA) was employed to handle a phase function with a strong forward peak in radiative transfer simulations. Furthermore, we combined the two-stream approximation (TSA) and SAA to improve the accuracy of radiative flux computations. It is shown that the SAA can improve the accuracy of downward flux computation, which also improves the associated upward flux computation due to energy conservation.

6) The major research findings were disseminated through 5 peer-reviewed publications (in addition, two manuscripts were submitted and are currently in review) and 12 conference presentations.

In addition to the research accomplishments summarized above, this project contains an educational component in training graduate students. In particular, two doctoral dissertations in conjunction with this project were completed.
